And you know, the expression the elephant

a big elephant standing in most math
classes in the US and in other countries. And that is the idea that only some kids
can be good at math.

Teachers believe that, parents believe it,
and students believe it. And that single idea is the root of a lot
of the underachievement in the US,

and I think as math teachers we have to
deal with this myth that's out there.

That being good at math is some kind of a
gift, and that some people are naturally good at

So we have decades now of research, really

You're not born with a math gift. Nobody's born with that, and everybody in

it's to do with the experiences people

the ideas they have about their own
ability and their own potential. So you probably know Carol Dweck released
a book which is

a New York Times best seller, in which she
summarized her research from a number of years which shows that people have one of
two mindsets.

So if you have a growth mindset, you
believe that the more work you do, the smarter you get.

If you have a fixed mindset, you believe
that you're either smart or you're not, and it turns out that about half of kids
have a fixed mindset in mathematics and

that mindset really harms their learning. So we also know that these different
mindsets go along with

different behaviors. So kids with a growth mindset are more
persistent. They're willing to learn from mistakes,
they're very determined to keep going and

they're encouraged by each other's
success. Kids with a fixed mindset are those you
probably know in your classroom,

you give them some challenging math work
to do, and they'll immediately say, I can't do this,
I need help.

We know that fixed mindset thinking
affects students from across the student spectrum, and

in fact, high achieving girls are some of
the worst hit by fixed mindset beliefs.

And we also know that praise is really
important in giving these different mindsets and the
way that many kids in the US have a fixed

mindset is because those parents in the US
often praise kids for being smart. So when they do something good, we say
you're really smart and what we now know

kids process about this, is that first
they think, oh, good I'm really smart but when they fail and they will, later, they
